rubit@zeroid.bit 
First of all, make sure, that the identity you're using on ThunderWave, is the same as on ZeroMe!

Ok, so you want to edit the file `data.json` in your user-data-directory, in this zites data-directory, in the ZeroNet-data-directory, so:
`[Path to ZeroNet-Installation-Directory]/data/1CWkZv7fQAKxTVjZVrLZ8VHcrN6YGGcdky/data/users/[Your Identity Address (which can be found by accessing the 0-menu, and scrolling down a bit)]/data.json`

Open that file with an editor, and search for/ scroll to the line `	"extra_data": [`
Beneath that line are 2 properties you need to set, e.g.:
```
    "avatar_type": [A NUMBER],
    "auth_address": "[YOUR IDENTITY ADDRESS]"
```
The property `auth_address` should already be set, and to use your ZeroMe-account's avatar you need to set `avatar_type` to `2`.
all the `[`', `]`' and their inbetween's text should be replaced with that value, described by the text, .. which is inbetween
also, the ZeroMe-account linked with the identity should have an avatar set, so one will be generated, if none exists

?![tc_52aab5fb-4e2f-ce66-b151-8cac7ecbc334] publicality@zeroid.bit you _could_ do the following (_*ast least IIRC*_):

1. Open your `data_private.json` file (you can get the path to your data directory with `/avatar`)
2. Click the group you want to delete in the UI
3. Wait until the first element in `group_messages_with` gets changed (you might just have to re-open the file, if your editor doesn't support external updates)
4. Delete the first element in `group_messages_with`
Also as a note: This does _not_ delete the messages you sent into the group you deleted!

and as the complete metadata and the message content is encrypted (for both, group chat and private chat), you will have to delete the messages manually (and as there is no real way except for calling some javascript to decrypt the messages by hand in the dev console, it'll probably take you quite a lot of time if you don't want to delete all group messages)

?![tc_8f5c50ad-635d-ddc8-bdd0-c37b54c48863] there is no online status, because that was not possible at the time I made this.
The alternative implementation I decided to add anyways is the "last seen" tab. It is reliable as much as the network is, and any logged in user will update their last seen timestamp when opening the zite or when sending a message (or pretty much any other action that modifies the data.json file)

Next thunderwave version will make use of the peermessage plugin, which means the online status can be implemented way better anyways
